column73: This project was one of the projects that was maintained by the company that I use to work for. My contribution there was very small, as we did not use it a lot.  But I guess this is a good example of the not very well documented project. this is the main obstacle for me when I would like to get involved in some project - not very clear README, missing documentation regarding code discipline for a particular project, not clear rules on how to get involved. That would be for me the main blocker.
column74: I don't contribute to this project anymore, in general, I think I pushed 1 or 2 things there, so it's one of the projects that I really don't fell that I am involved in. The main reason for that is that I don't work for the company in which GitHub organization this project is living and I don't use it for any other project.  So this is the project that has a really low priority for me. In my free time, I prefer to invest my time in other open-source projects.
column79: Of course. This is still a huge gap in the industry in general. I would love to collaborate with more women working together on the open-source projects. ( although, sometimes I don't really know the gender of the people that are involved in the project). But this might be reflection of the status of the industry in general, in my opinion. It doesn't necessarily mean that women are not involved in open-source. It might just mean that there is not many women that are present in the tech scene.

I don't know. I'm not even sure if there is any resistance from women engineers to participate in open source. I believe open source participation is a gender-agnostic activity. If there is a lack of women participating in open source projects, have you considered it might be because there are fewer female engineers than male ones? Having said that, maybe the solution is to get more female engineers in general. However, I really don't know the statistics in this regard. Maybe I'm biased but what I see in my day-to-day work is that we embrace contributions from anyone, no matter the gender, whether someone prefers indentation with tabs or spaces, etc. I perceive the larger IT engineering community to be very welcoming to everyone.

column74: Speaking of python_leaners_glossary in particular, I stopped contributing to it both because it seemed like the project wasn't going anywhere and due to a change of heart: the glossary was encompassing too wide a range of terms that I feel made it tedious to read for a beginner. As for other projects I usually stop contributing when I don't think there's anything more I can do (or bother to do depending on how time-consuming it would be to understand the entire codebase) or when I lose interest due to external factors.
column79: I do not believe anyone is preventing women from contributing to projects on GitHub. Perhaps seeing more women being active contributors to some projects would inspire others to do the same, but at the end of the day I feel like anyone, regardless of their gender, can create a pull request or start a project of their own should they feel like it.

column13: I get so much from the community that I feel where I can I need to give back when I can.
column73: Some project have specific coding standards which don't align with my own all the time which makes it a bit more difficult. In this case usually I only contribute if I have enough time to research their expectations and make sure I meet them. Most of my contributions are part of issues I've had myself, but sometimes my use case was too specific (eg: I had a bug for Percona, but that bug was introduced to fix a bug for Postgress, hence before creating the pull request I had to also test my code with postgress and with other variations of MySQL like MariaDB, on top of my use of Percona).
column74: No, but I do not do this as a full time job, I just try to commit meaningful changes that helped me in my own projects.
column79: There is an awful stigma with women in coding. I myself had an employee which thought I was favouring a women's work more just because of her looks, where in fact the quality of her code was what made me appreciate her. However, I think slowly, but steadily women's participation in coding and open source project in GitHub is growing. Perhaps friendly hackathons between man and women would serve well to encourage more women to participate, while eliminating the beliefs some man have.

column73: No. Perhaps lack of knowledge of a specific technical concept to contribute more, but I have always been concerned with studying the formats to contribute more.
column74: No.
column79: Courses and workshops with information on how GitHub works and how to collaborate. Sometimes women do not participate because they do not know how the platform works.
